Історія освоєння мінеральних ресурсів Демократичної Республіки Конго

jstat.data.Document.url: http://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/Історія освоєння мінеральних ресурсів Демократичної Республіки Конго

jstat.data.Document.html:
{{Cleanup-rewrite|date=May 2009}}
The [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] (abbreviated DR Congo or DRC), previously known as Zaire, is immensely rich in [[natural resources]]. However, mining activities have been closely linked to serious problems in the DRC. In September 2010, the government banned mining in the east of the country, attempting to crack down on illegal organisations and corruption.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.steelguru.com/metals_news/Congo_bans_mining_in_rebellious_eastern_provinces/165299.html |accessdate=2010-09-15 |title=Congo bans mining in rebellious eastern provinces }}</ref>
==Natural resources==
[[File:Terril Lubumbashi01.jpg|thumb|240px|right|Mine tailings at a [[Lubumbashi]] copper mine.]]
DR Congo is estimated to have $24 trillion (equivalent to the combined [[Gross Domestic Product]] of [[Europe]] and the [[United States]]) worth of untapped deposits of raw mineral ores, including the world’s largest reserves of cobalt and significant quantities of the world’s diamonds, gold and copper.<ref name='NewsAbout'>{{cite web | title = Congo with $24 Trillion in Mineral Wealth BUT still Poor | publisher = News About Congo | date = 2009-03-15 | url = http://www.newsaboutcongo.com/2009/03/congo-with-24-trillion-in-mineral-wealth-but-still-poor.html | accessdate = 2009-05-17}}</ref><ref name='AfricanBusinessFeb2009'>{{cite web | last = Morgan | first = M. J. | title = DR Congo's $24 trillion fortune. | publisher = African Business | date = 2009-02-01 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/DR+Congo's+$24+trillion+fortune.-a0193800184 | accessdate = }}</ref> The major ores extracted throughout the DRC are: *[[Cobalt]] *[[Diamonds]] *[[Gold]] *[[Copper]]
Much of the resource extraction is done in small operations,{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} known as "Artisanal and Small-Scale Mining" (ASM),<ref name='EITI Glossary'>{{cite web | last = Garrett | first = Nicholas | title = The Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) & Artisanal and Small-Scale Mining (ASM). Preliminary Observations from the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) | work = | publisher = Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative | year = 2007 | url = http://eitransparency.org/files/publication_file/NG_EITI_Report_22_10_Final.pdf | format = PDF | page = Glossary, Page 4 | accessdate = 2009-05-21 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> which are unregulated in the DRC.<ref name='EITIp6' /> Recently, more money is being invested into the extraction and refining of some of the ores found in the DRC, primarily copper and cobalt, which may help regulate the extraction and reduce environmental impacts.<ref name='MiningWeeklyNov2008'>{{cite web | last = Parker | first = Darren | title = EIA report gets thumbs-up in DRC | publisher = Mining Weekly | date = 2008-11-07 | url = http://www.miningweekly.com/article/eia-report-gets-thumbsup-in-drc-2008-11-07 | accessdate = 2009-05-17}}</ref> However, many ASM operations still exist for minerals such as [[coltan]] that can be mined with little capital investment.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} ASM operations employ a significant number of DRC's population, with estimates of up to one fifth of the country or 12.5 million people.<ref name='EITIp6'>{{cite web | last = Garrett | first = Nicholas | title = The Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) & Artisanal and Small-Scale Mining (ASM). Preliminary Observations from the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) | work = | publisher = Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative | year = 2007 | url = http://eitransparency.org/files/publication_file/NG_EITI_Report_22_10_Final.pdf | format = PDF | page = Page 6 | accessdate = 2009-05-21 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Because artisenal mining operations require little capital they are unregulated and occur primarily within protected areas, around endangered or threatened species.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} Artisenal mining often occurs in [[riparian]] zones.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}
During periods of violence, resources have been looted from the original collectors by both Congolese and foreign soldiers, and civilians or they are extracted by soldiers, locals organized by military commanders (much of the time [[Rwandan]] and [[Ugandan]] commanders) and by foreign nationals.<ref name='UN2001'>{{cite web | work = United Nations | title = Report of the panel of experts on the illegal exploitation of natural resources and other forms of wealth of the Democratic Republic of the Congo | publisher = www.un.org | date = 2001-04-12 | url = http://www.un.org/News/dh/latest/drcongo.htm | accessdate = 2009-05-17}}</ref> Problems stemming from mining practices include disruption of families, mining-related illnesses, environmental damage, child-labor, and abuse of women including prostitution and rape.<ref name='PACTasmWomen'>{{cite web | last = Hayes | first = Karen | title = Women in Artisanal Mining in the Democratic Republic of Congo | work = Pact Congo | publisher = www.pactworldwide.org | url = http://www.pactworld.org/galleries/default-file/Women%20in%20Artisanal%20Mining%20in%20the%20DRC.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2009-05-17}}</ref><ref name='ESKivus'>{{cite web | title = Mining, forest change and conflict in the Kivus, eastern Democratic Republic of Congo | work = | publisher = Institute for Environmental Security | date = May 2008 | url = http://www.envirosecurity.org/espa/PDF/Mining_forest_change_and_conflict_in_the_Kivus.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2009-05-17}}</ref>
==History== ===Mass scale looting=== After [[Rwanda]], [[Uganda]], and [[Burundi|Burundi’s]] successful invasion of eastern and southeastern DRC in the [[Second Congo War]], a great deal of what the [[UN]] labeled "mass scale looting" took root.<ref name='UN2001p8'>{{cite web | work = United Nations | title = Report of the panel of experts on the illegal exploitation of natural resources and other forms of wealth of the Democratic Republic of the Congo | publisher = www.un.org | date = 2001-04-12 | page = Page 8. | url = http://www.un.org/News/dh/latest/drcongo.htm | accessdate = 2009-05-17}}</ref> While initial invasion tactics were still being worked out, military commanders were making business deals with foreign companies for the Congo’s vast mineral reserves.<ref name='UN2001' /> Between September 1998 and August 1999 stockpiles of minerals, agricultural products, timber, and livestock were illegally confiscated from Congolese businesses, piled onto trucks, and sold as exports from the confiscating countries.<ref name='UN2001' /> Rwandan and Ugandan troops forced local businesses to close their doors by raiding and harassing civilian owners. Cars were stolen to such an extent that Uganda showed a 25 percent increase in automobiles in 1999.<ref name='UN2001' /> DARA-Forest Company illegally extracted and sold Congolese timber on the international market. An American Mineral Fields executive allowed rebels to use his private lear jet for a $1 billion mining deal.<ref name='Montague2002'>{{cite journal | last = Montague | first = Dena | title = Stolen goods: coltan and conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo. | journal = SAIS Review | volume = 22 | issue = 1 | pages = 103–118 | publisher = The Johns Hopkins University Press | location = Baltimore, Maryland | date = Winter-Spring 2002 | url = http://muse.jhu.edu/login?uri=/journals/sais_review/v022/22.1montague.pdf | doi = 10.1353/sais.2002.0016 | issn = 0036-0775 | accessdate = 2009-05-16 }}</ref> Some parallel the mining corporations rush to acquire [[coltan]] rich land in rebel territory of the DRC to the [[Conference of Berlin]] in 1885.<ref name='Montague2002' />
===Active extraction phase=== When the mass scale looting died down as stocks of minerals were depleted, soldiers were encouraged by commanders to take part in small-scale looting which started an "active extraction phase".<ref name='UN2001p8' /> Natural resources that were not stolen were often purchased with counterfeit Congolese francs which contributed to inflation. Air transportation companies that had operated in the Congo disappeared and were replaced by companies affiliated with foreign armies. The Congolese government lost out of profits from taxes on natural resources entering and leaving air fields because air services were controlled by foreign [[Rwandan]] and [[Ugandan]] troops who routinely exported coltan from the Congo. The increase in air transportation networks has also increased exploitation because of the emergence of new transport routes.<ref name='UN2001' />
Rwanda and Uganda have no known production sites for many of the minerals that were exported at vastly higher rates after their invasion of the DRC.<ref name='UN2001' /> "Free zone areas" make diamonds difficult to track because they can be repackaged and "legally" sold as diamonds from that country.<ref name='UN2001p17'>{{cite web | work = United Nations | title = Report of the panel of experts on the illegal exploitation of natural resources and other forms of wealth of the Democratic Republic of the Congo | publisher = www.un.org | date = 2001-04-12 | page = Page 17. | url = http://www.un.org/News/dh/latest/drcongo.htm | accessdate = 2009-05-17}}</ref> The DRC has been exporting few minerals since the invasion because the destruction of the rural infrastructure has caused mining and agricultural outputs to wane.<ref name='UN2001' /> [[Coltan]] is the most profitable mineral export from the Congo, but it is particularly difficult to track because it is often listed as [[cassiterite]], a mineral of lesser quality, for which export taxes are lower. Coltan has been illegally extracted and sold via Burundi since 1995, three years before the invasion.<ref name='UN2001' /> The [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF) states that [[Burundi]] has no "gold, diamonds, columbotantalite, copper, cobalt or basic metals" mining operations but has been exporting them since 1998.<ref name='UN2001p22'>{{cite web | work = United Nations | title = Report of the panel of experts on the illegal exploitation of natural resources and other forms of wealth of the Democratic Republic of the Congo | publisher = www.un.org | date = 2001-04-12 | page = Page 22. | url = http://www.un.org/News/dh/latest/drcongo.htm | accessdate = 2009-05-17}}</ref>
In the year 2000 Rwanda spent $70 million supporting about 25,000 troops and Uganda spent $110 million supporting twice as many troops.<ref name='UN2001' /> [[Rwanda]] and [[Uganda]] finance their war efforts through commercial deals, profit-sharing with companies, and taxation among other things. Rwandan soldiers often steal coltan collected by villagers and sell it to diamond dealers themselves. From dealing in coltan trade alone the Rwandan army may have collected $20 million per month and coltan profits have been used to pay back loans from foreign creditors.<ref name='UN2001' /> Rebel groups MLC, [[RCD-Goma]], and [[RCD-ML]] make their own deals with foreign businessmen for cash and/or military equipment.<ref name='UN2001' /> Battlefields are most commonly centered on areas that hold a lot of diamond and coltan potential and foreign armies occupation of the eastern region is maintained by illegal resource exploitation.<ref name='UN2001' />
For $1 million per month Rebel group RCD-Goma gave a coltan monopoly to SOMIGL which they in turn poured into efforts to gain control from RCD-ML for mineral-loaded land.<ref name='UN2001' /> To try to get fast cash to gain control of government land the DRC gave a diamond monopoly to International Diamond Industries (IDI) which was supposed to pay the government $20 million but paid only $3 million and continued to extract diamonds from the region and sell them internationally.<ref name='UN2001' /> Upon request of the IMF and WB the DRC is trying to liberalize diamond trade and IDI has threatened to sue because they had a contract they themselves did not honor.<ref name='UN2001' />
Corporations and Western countries purchasing coltan from Rwanda, Uganda, or Burundi are aware of its origin and aid from western donors is funneled directly into Rwandan and Ugandan war efforts. The German government even gave a loan to a private German citizen to build his coltan export business in the DRC, for which he enlisted the help of RCD-Goma soldiers.<ref name='UN2001' /> Mineral plunder in the DRC was easy once the central authority had collapsed because of the extremely weak financial system, as well as the apparent disregard of illegal conflicts on the part of proper standards by international corporations and governments that imported illegal minerals.<ref name='UN2001' /> The US has documented that many minerals are purchased from the DRC even though the DRC has no record of exporting them.<ref name='Montague2002' /> A lack of state stability combined with international corporations and foreign government’s interest in investing in Congolese mineral plunder increased the pace at which the DRC was shook off its fragile foundation. The UN does an excellent job of identifying the perpetrators of illegal resource exploitation in the DRC, but was not able to help prevent the economic exploitation of the country.<ref name='Montague2002' />
In September 2010, it was reported that the FDLR (Forces démocratiques de libération du Rwanda), a group of mostly Hutu rebels, was exploiting timber, gold and coltan in [[North Kivu]] and [[South Kivu]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.janes.com/news/security/jir/jir100916_1_n.shtml |accessdate=2010-09-16 |title=Criminal mines - Rebels continue to exploit the DRC's resources }}</ref>
== Foreign involvement == In 2011, at least twenty-five international mining companies were active in the D.R. Congo according to [[Datamonitor|Datamonitor 360]]. Canadian-domiciled mining companies had the highest presence, with nine in total: [[African Metals Corporation]], [http://www.banro.com Banro Resources Corporation], [http://www.brc-diamondcore.com BRC DiamondCore], El Niño Ventures Inc., [[First Quantum Minerals]], [http://www.icscopper.com/ ICS Copper Systems Ltd.], [[Lundin Mining|Lundin Mining Corp.]], as well as [[Anvil Mining|Anvil Mining Ltd.]], misidentified as Australian, and [[Katanga Mining|Katanga Mining Ltd]], misidentified as British. By comparison, six firms were incorporated in [[Australia]] (Austral Africa Resources Ltd., [[BHP Billiton|BHP Billiton Group]], [http://greenmachinecorp.com Green Machine Development Corporation], [http://www.lindianresources.com.au Lindian Resources Ltd.], [http://www.mawsonwest.com.au Mawson West Ltd.], [[Tiger Resources|Tiger Resources Ltd.]]), three in [[South Africa]] ([[African Rainbow Minerals]], [[AngloGold Ashanti]], [http://www.chrometco.co.za Chrometco Ltd.]), two in the [[United Kingdom]] ([[Mwana Africa|Mwana Africa PLC]], [[Randgold Resources|Randgold Resources Ltd.]]), two from the [[United States]] ([http://www.centuryaluminum.com Century Aluminum Co.], [[Freeport-McMoRan|Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc.]]), and one each from [[China]] ([http://cicresources.com CIC Mining Resources Ltd.], with Japanese Eco Energy Group's African subsidiary, [http://eco-project-ltd.com Eco Project Company Ltd.]), [[Morocco]] ([http://www.managem-ona.com Managem SA]), and [[Switzerland]] ([[Xstrata|Xstrata plc]]).<ref>Datamonitor Group . ''Datamonitor 360'', web database, London. Entry point: companies. Keywords: congo. Industry: Metals and Mining (34). http://www.datamonitor360.com/ (accessed February 7, 2011).</ref>
In 2008 and 2009, the Congolese operations of larger international companies, AngloGold Ashanti,<ref>AngloGold Ashanti. 2008. ''Our operations DRC 2008'', http://www.anglogold.co.za/NR/rdonlyres/0F71E463-1ABA-4A34-AF45-565E1DBD996A/0/drc.pdf (accessed February 5, 2011).</ref> BHP Billiton,<ref>BHP Billiton. ''Annual Report 2008'', http://www.bhpbilliton.com/annualreports2008/2008-business-review-and-annual-report/annual-report/information-on-the-company/minerals-exploration/index.html (accessed February 5, 2011)</ref> and Xstrata<ref>Xstrata plc. ''Annual Report 2009'', http://www.xstrata.com/annualreport/2009/strategy/chiefexecutivesreport/deliveringfuturegrowth.html (accessed February 5, 2011).</ref> were all in the exploration and development phase, while Canada had four companies, Anvil Mining,<ref name=anvil2010>Anvil Mining Ltd. ''Anvil Divests its Interest in the Dikulushi Tenements in the DRC and Updates Construction Progress at Kinsevere Stage II'', News Release, February 26, 2010, http://www.anvilmining.com/download.cfm?DownloadFile=B4F58533-C29E-198E-8153C59909147319 (accessed January 17, 2011).</ref> First Quantum Minerals,<ref name=fqm2009 /> Katanga Mining,<ref name=katangamining>{{cite web|title=''Our Operations-Project overview''|publisher=Katanga Mining|url=http://www.katangamining.com/kat/operations/pro_overview/|accessdate=January 17, 2011}}</ref> and Lundin Mining<ref name=lundin2009>{{cite web|publisher=Lundin Mining| title=''2009 Annual Filings'', p. 20 |url=http://www.lundinmining.com/i/pdf/2009_AF.pdf|format=PDF accessdate=January 17, 2011}}</ref> involved in large-scale commercial extraction for several years or more.
In August 2012 the Chinese firm [[Changfa Mineral Resources]] acquired the Mokambo Copper mine project on the [[Mufulira]] and [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] border and it is expected to create around 3,000 new jobs when it begins full-scale operations this year.<ref>[http://www.times.co.zm/?p=10519 Majie Sayila, "New mine to create over 3,000 jobs", ''Times of Zambia'' (31 August 2012)]</ref>
=== Canada ===
{{Main|Canadian mining in the Democratic Republic of the Congo}}
According to the Congolese government, Canadian companies in 2009 held US$4.5 billion in mining-related investments in the DR Congo.<ref name=rdc2009>République Démocratique du Congo. Cabinet du Chef de l'Etat. 2009. "Le Premier ministre informé des activités des sociétés canadiennes en RDC", 10 juin 2009, http://www.cinqchantiers-rdc.com/article.php3?id_article=1800 (accessed March 28, 2011).</ref> The DRC ranked either first or second-largest among African countries for Canadian mining at the end of the 2000s.<ref name=miron2010>Miron, Michel. 2010. "Africa: Cumulative Canadian Mining Assets" (calculated at acquisition, construction or fabricating costs, and includes capitalized exploration and development costs, non-controlling interests, and excludes liquid assets, cumulative depreciation, and write-off), Minerals and Metals Sector, Natural Resources Canada, internal document.</ref> The [[Government of Canada]] reported 28 Canadian mining and exploration companies operating in the D.R. Congo between 2001 and 2009, with four carrying out commercial-scale extraction; collectively, these companies' [[Canadian mining in the Democratic Republic of the Congo#Cumulative Canadian mining assets|assets]] in the DRC ranged between Cdn.$161 mill. in 2003 and $5.2 bill. in 2008.<ref name=miron2010 /> The [[Government of Canada|Government of Canada's]] mining ministry, [[Natural Resources Canada]] estimated that in 2009, Canadian-owned mining assets in the D.R. Congo were valued at Cdn.$3.3 billion, ten times more than in 2001, making them the second-highest African share after Madagascar, and representing a sixth of total Canadian mining assets in Africa.<ref name=miron2010 /> [[Natural Resources Canada]] valued Canadian mining assets in the DRC at Cdn.$2.6 bn. in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last=Government of Canada|title=Canada - Democratic Republic of Congo Relations|url=http://www.canadainternational.gc.ca/congo/bilateral_relations_bilaterales/canada_drc-rdc.aspx?view=d|publisher=The Embassy of Canada, Kinshasa 1, Democratic Republic of Congo|accessdate=2012-01-30}}</ref>
The majority of Canadian-domiciled mining companies currently or previously active in the DR Congo have been involved in either exploration and development or large-scale mining of the Congo's copper and cobalt resources.<ref name=wikicanmindrccu>[[Canadian mining in the Democratic Republic of the Congo#Copper and cobalt]]</ref> Using [[World Bank]] estimates, Garrett and Lintzer<ref name=garrett2010>{{cite journal | last1 = Garrett | first1 = Nicholas | last2 = Lintzer | first2 = Marie | year = 2010 | title = Can Katanga's mining sector drive growth and development in the DRC? | url = | journal = Journal of Eastern African Studies | volume = 4 | issue = 3| pages = 400–424 | doi = 10.1080/17531055.2010.517408 }}</ref> reported that three Canadian companies [[First Quantum Minerals]], [[Lundin Mining]] (in partnership with the US firm [[Freeport-McMoRan|Freeport McMoRan Copper & Gold]]) and [[Katanga Mining]] will have been responsible for more than two-thirds of total Congolese copper output from 2008 to 2013, and for more than two-thirds of total Congolese cobalt output from 2008 to 2014. These companies, along with Canadian-incorporated [[Anvil Mining]], have undertaken industrial copper and cobalt extraction during 2000-2010.<ref name=wikicanmindrccu /> Another eight junior Canadian mining companies including [[Ivanhoe Mines|Ivanhoe Nickel & Platinum Ltd.]] and [[Rubicon Minerals Corporation]], as of early 2011, reporting holdings of copper and cobalt concessions in Katanga province.<ref name=wikicanmindrccu /> Nine Canadian junior mining companies, including [[Kinross Gold Corp.]], previously held copper and/or cobalt concessions, but have since abandoned them, or had them acquired by other Canadian or South African firms.<ref name=wikicanmindrccu />
[[Banro Resources Corporation]] has since 1996 owned [[gold]] concessions in [[South Kivu]] and [[Maniema]] provinces of the DRC,<ref>Critchley, Barry. 1996. "Banro goes into Africa with $18M", ''The Financial Post'', 5 June 1996, p. 5.</ref> and began gold production in 2011. Six other Canadian companies previously owned Congolese gold properties, including [[Barrick Gold]] (1996–1998),<ref name=barrick1996>Anonymous. 1996. "American Barrick Steps In", ''Africa Energy & Mining '', N. 175, February 14, 1996.</ref><ref name=barrick1998>Anonymous. 1998. "Barrick Steps Back", ''Africa Energy & Mining'', N. 228, May 13, 1998.</ref> and [[Moto Gold Mines|Moto Goldmines]] (2005–2009).<ref name=wikicanmindrcau>[[Canadian mining in the Democratic Republic of the Congo#Gold]]</ref> In the [[diamond]]s sector, Montreal-based [[Dan_Gertler#Congo_diamond_trade|Emaxon Financial International Inc.]] is currently active,<ref>Anonymous. 2003. "Emaxon to finance expansion of MIBA's diamond mines", October 27, 2003, ''PR Newswire Europe''</ref><ref>Dougherty, Carter. 2003. "Sifting Through a Dark Business; Does Congo's diamond trade defy change? Kimberley reforms may not be working fully", ''Newsweek International'', December 8, 2003.</ref> while seven other Canadian junior companies reported previous ownership of properties in the DRC during 2001-2009, including [http://www.canafgroup.com Canaf Group Inc.] and [http://www.brc-diamondcore.com BRC DiamondCore].<ref name=wikicanmindrcta>[[Canadian mining in the Democratic Republic of the Congo#Diamonds]]</ref> Montreal-based [http://www.shamikaresources.com Shamika Resources] is exploring for [[tantalum]], [[niobium]], [[tin]] and [[tungsten]] in the Eastern DRC and [http://www.loncor.com Loncor Resources] is exploring for gold, platinum, tantalum and other metals.<ref name=wikicanmindrcta>[[Canadian mining in the Democratic Republic of the Congo#Tantalum (coltan), niobium, tin and tungsten]]</ref> Two Canadian-registered companies own petroleum concessions in the DRC: [[Heritage Oil|Heritage Oil plc]], whose founder and Chief Executive Officer is [[Tony Buckingham]], and [http://www.energulf.com EnerGulf Resources Inc.].<ref name=wikicanmindrcpet>[[Canadian mining in the Democratic Republic of the Congo#Petroleum]]</ref>
Since 2009, two Canadian companies, [[First Quantum Minerals]]<ref name=fqm2009>{{cite web|publisher=First Quantum Minerals, Ltd.|title=''Annual Report 2009'', p.11|url= http://www.first-quantum.com/i/pdf/2009AnnualReport.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate= January 17, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|publisher=First Quantum Minerals.|title= ''Bwana - Lonshi Fact Sheet New Design - First Quantum''|url=http://www.first-quantum.com/i/pdf/Bwana_Lonshi_Fact.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=accessed January 17, 2011}}</ref> and [[Heritage Oil|Heritage Oil plc]],<ref name=heritage2010>Heritage Oil PLC. ''Annual Report & Accounts 2009'', p. 24, http://www.sedar.com/DisplayProfile.do?lang=EN&issuerType=03&issuerNo=00026779 (accessed January 20, 2011).</ref> have had their mining permits revoked by the DRC government. First Quantum closed all its Congolese operations during 2010, and initiated, in concert with other stakeholders, international arbitration proceedings against the Congolese government.<ref>First Quantum Minerals Ltd. 2011. ''2011 Annual Report'', p. 7, 26-27, 33, http://sedar.com/DisplayProfile.do?lang=EN&issuerType=03&issuerNo=00006237 (accessed April 26, 2011).</ref> The Congolese revocation was linked to alleged obstruction attempts made by the [[Government of Canada]]<ref name=theprovince2010>Anonymous. 2010. "Canada cool to Congo", ''The Province. Vancouver, B.C.'', July 2, 2010. pg. A.35.</ref> in the negotiation of [[International Monetary Fund]] and World Bank [[debt relief]] to the DRC in 2010.<ref name=bouw2010>Bouw, Brenda. 2010. "Congo wins debt relief despite Canadian concerns", ''The Globe and Mail'', July 2, 2010, pg. A.13.</ref><ref>Anonymous. 2010. "Canada requests delay in Congo debt relief", Wed Jun 30, 2010, 5:48am GMT, http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE65T01U20100630?sp=true (accessed April 26, 2011).</ref> First Quantum, which was active in the D.R. Congo since 1997,<ref>First Quantum Minerals Ltd. 1998. ''1997 Annual Report'', p. 3, 17 of 33, http://sedar.com/DisplayProfile.do?lang=EN&issuerType=03&issuerNo=00006237 (accessed April 26, 2011).</ref> reported overall corporate social responsibility contributions amounting to 3.0% of the Congolese [[gross national income]] in 2009,<ref>First Quantum Minerals. 2010. ''Corporate Sustainability Report'', p. 12 http://www.first-quantum.com/i/pdf/FQM_Corporate_Sustainability_Report.pdf (accessed January 31, 2011).</ref> and was reported to be the DRC's largest taxpayer that year, accounting for between one-eighth and one-quarter of total collected revenue.<ref name=garrett2010 /> In 2012, it was announced that First Quantum's legal dispute ended in an out of court settlement.<ref>{{cite journal|last=McClearn|first=Matthew|title=Quantum finds solace. How the Canadian mining company got its money back|journal=Canadian Business|date=1/24|year=2012|volume=85|issue=1/2|accessdate=3 March 2012}}</ref>
The first DR Congo project funded by the [[World Bank|World Bank Group's]] [[Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency]] (MIGA), was awarded in 2005 to Canada and Ireland as co-investors, on behalf of the [[Dikulushi Mine]] held by [http://www.anvilmining.com Anvil Mining Ltd.] in Katanga Province.<ref>Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency. Home > Projects > Advanced Search > Anvil Mining Congo, SARL, http://www.miga.org/projects/index_sv.cfm?pid=634 (accessed April 8, 2011).</ref> Four of the nine D.R. Congo projects sponsored or proposed for sponsorship by the World Bank's [[International Finance Corporation]] up to early 2011 were for Canadian-owned companies active in the DRC: to Kolwezi/Kingamyambo Musonoi Tailings SARL owned by [[Adastra Minerals|Adastra Minerals Inc.]] ($50.0m., invested in 2006),<ref>International Finance Corporation. Summary of Project Information (SPI), Kingamyambo Musonoi Tailings SARL, http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/projects/88701E7FE15991AD852576BA000E2C86 (accessed April 8, 2011).</ref> [[Africo Resources Ltd.]] (acquisition of Cdn.$8m. in Africo shares, invested in 2007),<ref>International Finance Corporation. Africo Resources Limited, Environmental & Social Review Summary, http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/0/75A0EBB9C9548C68852576C10080CD35 (accessed April 8, 2011).</ref> and Kingamyambo Musonoi Tailings SARL as acquired by First Quantum, proposed in 2009 at a value of US$4.5 m. in equity funding.<ref>International Finance Corporation. Kingamyambo Musonoi Tailings SARL, Summary of Proposed Investment, http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spiwebsite1.nsf/f451ebbe34a9a8ca85256a550073ff10/49f16fb4c528c963852576ba000e2d57?OpenDocument (accessed April 8, 2011).</ref><ref>International Finance Corporation. "Search IFC Projects", Type of project: Investment Projects, Project country: "Congo, Democratic Republic of", http://www.ifc.org/projects (accessed April 8, 2011).</ref>
The killing by Congolese military of between seventy and one hundred civilians in the town of [[Kilwa, Democratic Republic of the Congo|Kilwa]], nearby Anvil Mining's Dikulushi mine in 2004 has resulted in legal proceedings against Anvil Mining in the DR Congo and Canada, and investigations by the [[Australian Federal Police]] and by the World Bank's [http://www.cao-ombudsman.org Office of the Compliance Advisor/Ombudsman].<ref>[[Canadian_mining_in_the_Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo#Anvil_Mining_and_Kilwa_incident]]</ref>
In 2011, Canada's [[Fraser Institute]] annual survey of mining executives reported the DRC's ranking of its mining exploration investment favourability fell from eighth-poorest in 2006 down to second-poorest in 2010, among 45 African, Asian and Latin American countries and 24 jurisdictions in Canada, Australia and the United States, and this was attributed to "the uncertainty created by the nationalization and revision of contracts by the Kabila government".<ref>McMahon, Fred; Cervantes, Miguel. 2011. ''Survey of Mining Companies 2010/2011'', Vancouver: The Fraser Institute, p. 7, 11-12, http://www.fraserinstitute.org/research-news/display.aspx?id=17302 (accessed April 26, 2011).</ref>
== Impacts of natural resource extraction on the DRC == ===Environmental impacts===
Resource extraction has many impacts on the cultural and environmental diversity of the DRC; it is difficult to quantify the environmental degradation of the country. As it is unstable and difficult for researchers to enter and do work in the country also it is always difficult to quantify loss of biodiversity as animals are mobile and the lack of roads and navigable rivers make transportation into the wilderness areas difficult for researchers.<ref name='BSP2001'>{{cite web | last = Hart | first = Terese | coauthors = Mwinyhali, Robert | title = Armed Conflict and Biodiversity in Sub-Saharan Africa: The Case of the Democratic Republic of Congo | work = Biodiversity Support Program | publisher = www.worldwildlife.org | year = 2001 | url = http://www.worldwildlife.org/bsp/publications/search.cfm?pubno=143 | accessdate = }}</ref><ref name='Draulans'>{{cite journal | last = Draulans | first = Dirk Van | coauthors = Krunkelsven, Ellen | title = The impact of war on forest areas in the Democratic Republic of Congo | journal = Oryx | volume = 36 | issue = 1 | pages = 35–40 | publisher = | location = | year = 2002 | doi = 10.1017/S0030605302000066 | url = http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=96871 | accessdate = 2009-05-16}}</ref>
Mining can be an intensive process and has affected some wilderness areas, including national parks and wildlife reserves such as [[Kahuzi-Biega National Park|Kahuzi-Biega]] and the [[Okapi Wildlife Reserve]], both of which are [[world heritage site]]s. Mining in these areas is typically artisanal; a small scale mining method that takes place in river beds and can, cumulatively, be very environmentally damaging. Artisanal mining degrades riparian zones, creating [[erosion]] and heavy [[silting]] of the water. The [[tailings]] are often dumped into the rivers and could be contaminated with [[mercury (element)|mercury]] and [[cyanide]] degrading the health of the river systems putting the wildlife and people at risk.<ref name='Sheppard2001'>{{cite web | last = Sheppard | first = David | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Coltan Mining in World Heritage Sites in the Democratic Republic of Congo. | work = The World Conservation Union ([[IUCN]]) | publisher = | date = 2001-04-23 | url = http://tierra.rediris.es/coltan/coltanenvir.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2009-05-16}}</ref><ref name='iied2002'>{{cite web | title = Breaking New Ground: Mining, Minerals and Sustainable Development - Final Report, Ch. 13 | publisher = International Institute for Environment and Development | year = 2002 | url = http://www.iied.org/pubs/pdfs/9084IIED.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2009-05-16}}</ref> Miners and refugees are relocating to parks in search of minerals; a reported 10,000 have moved into [[Kahuzi-Biéga National Park|Kahuzi-Biega]] and 4,000 to the [[Okapi Wildlife Reserve]]. This increases the pressures on wildlife as timber is cut down and used as [[wood fuel|fuel wood]] to cook with, and wildlife is killed for its meat. Also, as people enter into these areas animals such as primates are collected for trade on the black market. Others are poached for their hides, or for the tusks such as elephants.<ref name='BSP2001' /><ref name='Draulans' />
The extent of logging has been difficult to quantify. Much of the logging that occurs is primarily for target hardwood species, rather than clear-cutting which can be assessed by satellite imaging.<ref name='BSP2001' /> Observations have shown an increased number of logging trucks moving across borders. Logging destroys valuable habitat for animals and increases the access into forested areas making it easier for poachers, miners and refugees to access areas.<ref name='BSP2001' />
===Socio-cultural repercussions=== There are many factors which contributed to the Democratic Republic of the Congo’s severe socio-economic hardships, and not all resource extraction operations have had an entirely negative impact on Congolese society at large. That said, the negative consequences brought about by some forms of resource extraction, such as coltan mining, are devastating. For example, worldwide, as demand for goods has increased, so has the demand for tantalum, or coltan (DCA 2006) and reportedly, "much of the finance sustaining the civil wars in Africa, especially in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, is directly connected to Coltan profits" (DCA 2006, pp 1).
Within the DRC, there are both wars between Congolese and conflicts between neighboring nations. Although these wars have components of inter-tribal conflict, in several cases the conflicts have been induced by external forces, such as changes in international support and demands for resource extraction.<ref name='JAS2003'>{{cite journal | last = Carayannis | first = Tatiana | title = The Complex Wars of the Congo: Towards a New Analytic Approach | journal = Journal of Asian and African Studies | volume = 38 | issue = 2-3 | pages = 232–255 | year = 2003 | doi = 10.1177/002190960303800206 | url = http://jas.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/38/2-3/232 | accessdate = 2009-05-16}}</ref> As a result of tantalum mining and wars, societies in the eastern regions of the Congo are experiencing heightened physical and economic insecurity,<ref name='CAFOD2007'>{{Cite book | last = (CAFOD) | first = Catholic Agency for Overseas Development | publisher = United Nations Relief Web | title = Potentially rich but partially ruined. | date = 2007-01-03 | url = http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900sid/EGUA-6X4R3Y | accessdate = 2009-05-16}}</ref><ref name='Jackson2002'>{{cite journal | last = Jackson | first = Stephen | title = Making a killing: Criminality and coping in the Kivu War economy. | journal = Review of African Political economy. | volume = 29 | issue = 93-94 | pages = 517–536 | publisher = Routledge | year = 2002 | issn = 1740-1720 | url = http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/title~content=a905425507~db=all~tab=jdb_table_of_contents_previous | accessdate = 2009-05-16}}</ref> health problems and human-rights violations.
In the [[Ituri province|Ituri]] region, a [[Ituri Conflict|violent conflict]] is occurring between the [[Lendu]] and the [[Hema people|Hema]] tribes. Analysts have determined that the conflict has intertribal as well as economic components brought about by the patterns of coltan extraction.
A health problem brought about by resource extraction is the effect of [[tantalite]] (coltan) mining on women and children who work in the mines. As more women are turning to mining for income, they are faced with dangerous tasks such as pounding the stone which contains [[tantalum]]. The release of fibers that get into the lungs is affecting both the women and their babies, who are passengers on their mother’s backs.<ref name='IRIN2002'>{{cite web | title = DRC: Two groups critical of coltan mining in the east | publisher = UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs - Integrated Regional Information Networks (IRIN). | date = 2002-01-16 | url = http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=29789 | accessdate = 2009-05-17}} </ref> "More worrying, the majority of babies, often on the backs of their mothers during the horrendous task of pounding coltan, have started showing similar signs of disease and pain to those of their mothers".<ref name='IRIN2002' />
Child labour is common in DRC, and the mining industry is no exception.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalmarch.org/worstformsreport/world/congo-dem-rep.html |accessdate=2010-09-16 |title=Worst Forms of Child Labour - Congo, Dem. Rep.: Global March Against Child Labour |date=2004-10-07 }}</ref> Children in the region are also being forced and coerced to become soldiers.
The resulting labor shift from farming to mining has been linked to food shortages and insecurity.<ref name='Jackson2002' /> The DRC has some of the richest soils and favorable climatic conditions for food production on the African continent. Before Mobutu’s reign, the DRC was one of the major exporters of food to the rest of Africa. "The richly fertile soil (especially that in the eastern highlands which is volcanic in origin) could produce enough food to feed half of Africa, but the country is so poor that at present its people do not produce enough food to feed themselves".<ref name='HealeDRC'>{{cite book | last = Heale | first = Jay | title = Democratic Republic of the Congo | publisher = Marshall Cavendish Corporation | year = 1999 | location = Tarrytown, NY | pages = | url = http://books.google.com/?id=vjcMQlKbhL0C | isbn = 978-0-7614-0874-1}}</ref>
===Environmental and occupational health===
Civilian populations have suffered significant health impacts from mining and the associated conflicts. The exploitation of natural resources is directly related to the ongoing conflict in the region and subsequent humanitarian crises.<ref name='UN2001'/><ref name="Hayes20032">{{cite journal | last = Hayes | first = K | coauthors = Burge, R | title = Coltan Mining in the Democratic Republic of Congo: How tantalum-using industries can commit to the reconstruction of the DRC | journal = Fauna & Flora International | volume = | issue = | pages = | publisher = Fauna & Flora International. | location = Cambridge, UK. | date = Winte2003 | url = | doi = | issn = | accessdate = 11/4/11 }}</ref><ref name='Oxfam2001'>{{cite web | last = | first = | title = No End in Sight: The human tragedy of the conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo | publisher = Oxfam GB | year = 2001 | url = http://policy-practice.oxfam.org.uk/publications/no-end-in-sight-the-human-tragedy-of-the-conflict-in-the-democratic-republic-of-114040 | accessdate = 11/4/11 }}</ref> These health impacts come from labor, human rights violations, and collapse of social norms.
Health and safety standards are largely specified in Congolese law, but government agencies have not enforced them effectively. Because of this, there are many grave labor violations. Minimum wage laws are rarely followed at mines. Work week hour standards, overtime payment and rest periods are largely ignored as well. Child labor laws are rarely enforced. Child laborers make up to 30% of the mining labor force. Because of all of this, deaths and violent injury at mining work sites are common place.<ref name='StateDept2011'>{{cite web | last = Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor | first = | title = 2010 Human Rights Report: Democratic Republic of the Congo | publisher = US Department of State | year = 2011 | url = http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2010/af/154340.htm | accessdate = 11/4/11}}</ref><ref name='StateDept2008'>{{cite web | last = Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor | first = | title = 2007 Human Rights Report: Democratic Republic of the Congo | publisher = US Department of State | year = 2008 | url = http://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2007/100475.htm | accessdate = 11/4/11}}</ref>
Civilians, including large numbers of children, have been regularly forced into labor, especially as miners and soldiers. Many miners become enslaved when they fail to pay back debt to their employer.<ref name='StateDept2008'/>
Rebel and militia groups commit widespread human rights abuses, including rape, enslavement, torture, disappearances and killing of civilians.<ref name="Peterman20112">{{cite journal | last = Peterman | first = A | coauthors = Palermo, T & Bredenkamp, C | title = Estimates and Determinants of Sexual Violence Against Women in the Democratic Republic of Congo | journal = American Journal of Public Health | volume = 101 | issue = | pages = 1060–1067 | publisher = | location = Washington, DC | year = 2011 | doi = 10.2105/AJPH.2010.300070 | issn = | accessdate = 11/4/11 | pmid=21566049}}</ref> These groups compete for finances from illegal mining.<ref name="Hayes20032"/> Reports indicate that corporations have facilitated these abuses by obtaining minerals from areas controlled by these groups.<ref name='StateDept2011'/>
Sexual violence is an especially widespread and devastating issue across the country. Between 1.69 and 1.80 million women reported being raped in their lifetime.<ref name="Peterman20112"/> Around mines, [[survival sex|survival prostitution]], sex slavery, and forced child prostitution has been observed.<ref name='StateDept2011'/> This widespread sexual violence contributes to the spread of HIV/AIDS, as well.<ref name="klare2011">{{cite journal | last = Klare | first = MT | title = Public Health Implications of Resource Wars | journal = American Journal of Public Health | volume = | issue = | pages = | publisher = | location = Washington, DC | year = 2011 | url = | doi = | issn = | accessdate = 11/4/11 }}</ref>
During the Second Congo War, 3 million civilians died, largely attributed to malnutrition or disease. Nearly as many were internally displaced.<ref name="Hayes20033">{{cite journal | last = Hayes | first = K | coauthors = Burge, R | title = Coltan Mining in the Democratic Republic of Congo: How tantalum-using industries can commit to the reconstruction of the DRC | journal = Fauna & Flora International | volume = | issue = | pages = | publisher = Fauna & Flora International. | location = Cambridge, UK. | date = Winte2003 | url = | doi = | issn = | accessdate = 11/4/11 }}</ref> Destruction of agricultural land and cattle, and the draw of money through mining led to a decrease in food access and increase in malnutrition.<ref name='Oxfam2001'/><ref name="cox2011">{{cite journal | last = Cox | first = TP | title = Farming the battlefield: the meaning of war, cattle and soil in South Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo | journal = Disasters | volume = | issue = | pages = | publisher = Overseas Development Institute | location = | year = 2011 | url = | doi = 10.1111/j.1467-7717.2011.01257.x | issn = | accessdate = 11/4/11 }}</ref>
Assessment and assistance by outside organizations has been difficult. Access to mining areas is limited by corrupt government officials and hostile militias.<ref name='Oxfam2001'/> Recently, reductions in mortality rate have been documented. This is linked to improvements in security, humanitarian and politic issues.<ref name="coghlan2009">{{cite journal | last = Coghlan | first = B | coauthors = et al | title = Update on mortality in the Democratic Republic of Congo: results from a third nationwide survey | journal = Disasters | volume = 3 | issue = 2 | pages = 88–96 | publisher = Disaster Med Public Health Prep | location = | year = 2011 | url = | doi = 10.1111/j.1467-7717.2011.01257.x | issn = | accessdate = 11/4/11 }}</ref> These improvements, however, are limited by continued unregulated mining. Exploitation of natural resources by rebel groups supplying international corporations continues to impair the growth of peace and stability.<ref name='Montague2002'/>
In the United States, the [[Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act]] requires retailers and manufacturers to track and publish the amount of [[conflict minerals]] sourced from the Democratic Republic of the Congo. A recent event, the exact regulations have not yet been determined.

Sizer, Nigel. | title = Forests and the Democratic Republic of Congo. Opportunity in a time of crisis. | publisher = World Resources Institute | date = June 1998 | url = http://pdf.wri.org/drc_eng.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2009-05-20}} *{{cite book | last = Wolvekamp | first = Paul | coauthors = Usher, Ann Danaiya.
